title: CPR for Infants
summary: Life-saving technique for performing CPR on infants (under 1 year old) who are unresponsive and not breathing normally.

steps.title: Check Responsiveness and Call for Help
steps.description: Tap the infant's foot and call their name loudly. If unresponsive, have someone call 911 immediately. If alone with no phone, perform 2 minutes of CPR before leaving to call 911.

steps.title: Position the Infant
steps.description: Place the infant on a firm, flat surface. Tilt their head back slightly to a neutral position (not as far as for adults). The infant's head should be in a 'sniffing' position to open the airway.

steps.title: Check for Breathing
steps.description: Look, listen, and feel for normal breathing for no more than 10 seconds. Occasional gasps are not normal breathing. If not breathing normally, begin chest compressions immediately.

steps.title: Perform Chest Compressions
steps.description: Place 2 fingers in the center of the chest just below the nipple line. Press down about 1.5 inches (4 cm) at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute. Allow complete chest recoil between compressions. Count aloud: '1, 2, 3... 30'.

steps.title: Give Rescue Breaths
steps.description: After 30 compressions, cover the infant's mouth and nose with your mouth, creating a seal. Give 2 gentle puffs of air, each lasting 1 second. Watch for the chest to rise with each breath. If the chest doesn't rise, reposition the head and try again.

steps.title: Continue CPR Cycles
steps.description: Continue cycles of 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths. Do not stop until emergency services arrive, the infant starts breathing normally, or you become too exhausted to continue.

warnings: Use only 2 fingers for compressions, not the whole hand
Be gentle with rescue breaths - infant lungs are small and delicate
Do not shake the infant to check responsiveness
Never perform CPR on an infant who is conscious and breathing
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 immediately for any unresponsive infant
If alone, perform 2 minutes of CPR before calling 911
Continue CPR until professional help arrives
preventionTips: Always supervise infants, especially during feeding and sleep
Learn infant CPR from a certified instructor
Keep small objects away from infants to prevent choking
Follow safe sleep guidelines to reduce SIDS risk
